Safe Region:
The safe region is located in the central-left portion of the image, where there is exposure of the fatty tissue and peritoneal attachments above the gallbladder. This area appears as a lighter, yellowish tissue where dissection may proceed safely. This zone avoids critical structures and follows along the naturally present dissection plane between the gallbladder and its surrounding tissue. The surgical instruments are accurately positioned to dissect within this safe area.

Unsafe Region:
The unsafe region is primarily situated in the lower right part of the image, where darker and more vascular tissues can be seen, possibly indicating the presence of major vessels and ducts. This area likely encompasses components of the hepatocystic triangle, where the cystic duct and artery are found. The tissue here appears more complex and dissection should be avoided until structures are clearly identified to prevent any damage.

The key consideration is maintaining clear visualization of the gallbladder’s dissection plane while avoiding deeper penetration near vascular and ductal structures in the unsafe region. The boundary between these regions is defined by tissue coloration and vascularity seen in the image.
